appendix.title: Official TAN keywords
appendix.para: In this section are collected all official TAN keywords, i.e., built-in values of @which for certain elements. Remember, these keywords are not @xml:id values. They contain punctuation, spaces, and so forth. For more on the use of these keywords, see @which, specific elements, or various examples.

section.title: TAN keywords for types of divisions
section.para: Definitive list of key terms used for textual divisions.

table.title: TAN keywords for types of divisions

entry.para: division used particularly by Thomas Aquinas
Conceptual book, not a physical one.
Division in medieval western literature
Terminology used of medieval works, e.g., Gratian.
Terminology used of medieval works, e.g., Gratian.
Terminology used of medieval works, e.g., Gratian.
A physical line of text on the page, not to be confused with a line of poetry, which may take multiple physical lines.
A generic division of a larger textual unit
division used particularly by Thomas Aquinas
division used particularly by Thomas Aquinas

Divisions of a column. Many early large books with two columns per page were printed with a few letters marking the vertical axis of the column, to make referencing easier. This is seen, for example, in the Patrologia Latina and Patrologia Graeca.
An alternative rendition of a passage. It is assumed that every variant will have at least one sibling.

section.title: TAN keywords for types of normalizations
section.para: Definitive list of key terms used for normalizations to texts.

table.title: TAN keywords for types of normalizations

entry.para: Discretionary word-break line-end hyphens have been deleted.

General Punctuation spaces (U+2000..U+200B) to regular space have been replaced with regular space. Equivalent to fn:replace('[\x{2000} \x{2001} \x{2002} \x{2003} \x{2004} \x{2005} \x{2006} \x{2007} \x{2008} \x{2009} \x{200A} \x{200B}]',' ')
Footnote or endnote signals (frequently superscript numbers or letters) have been deleted.
Footnotes or endnotes have been deleted.
Editorial comments have been deleted.
Reference pointers to other texts, both internal (cross-references) and external (citations of primary or secondary sources) have been deleted.
Reference milestones such as page numbers and section numbers have been deleted.
All ligatures have been converted into constituent letters.
All combining letters (U+0363..U+036F) have been converted to their corresponding ASCII counterpart.
All orthography (spelling) has been tacitly corrected to standard forms.
All punctuation has been tacitly corrected to standard forms.
All punctuation has been removed.
All letters have been tacitly capitalized according to standard forms.
All uppercase letters converted to lowercase.
All lowercase letters converted to uppercase.
Printed music has been removed.
All prepunctuation space has been corrected according to standard forms.
All non-NFC-compliant Unicode converted to normalized Unicode. Same effect as if applying normalize-unicode().
HTML converted to TAN-T format

section.title: TAN keywords for types of relationships
section.para: Definitive list of key terms used for describing relationships between digital files.

table.title: TAN keywords for types of relationships

entry.para: Digital or nondigital entity that was helpful in creating or editing the present file. This may be useful for crediting a helpful starting point.
Points to a TAN file that uses the current file as a source.
Used by a class 1 TAN file to point to another that offers the same work but in a different version.
Background information about one or more concepts mentioned in a TAN file.
The edition from which the current one branches.
An edition branched off from the current edition.
An edition that shares the same parent as the current edition.
An edition that is an anscestor to the current edition.
An edition that descends from the current edition.
An edition that shares the same ancestor as the current edition

Used by a class 1 file to point to another class 1 file that contains the identical transcription for the same version of the same work on the same textual object, but divides that transcription into a different reference system. If this value is invoked, the concatenated text content of <body> must be identical, after space normalization. This <relationship> is useful for developing a concordance between alternative reference systems for the same text.

Used by a class 1 file to point to another class 1 file that treats the same version of the same work on the same textual object, but normalizes the transcription differently. This <relationship> may be valuable in cases where normalization standards for a particular language are not settled, and users may prefer one convention over the other, but wish to have access to another approach to normalization.
TAN file superseded by the present file, and part of the same editorial stream. The alterations are considered not to warrant a new @id in the rootmost element.

TAN file that supersedes the present file, and part of the same editorial stream. The alterations have not been significant enough to warrant a new @id in the rootmost element. This is useful for officially deprecating a TAN file without deleting it.

section.title: TAN keywords for types of rights
section.para: This file depends largely upon the vocabulary of Creative Commons

table.title: TAN keywords for types of rights

section.title: TAN keywords for types of token definitions
section.para: Definitive list of key terms used to name standard token definitions.

table.title: TAN keywords for types of token definitions

entry.para: General tokenization pattern for any language, treating not only series of letters as word tokens but also individual non-letter characters (e.g., punctuation).
General tokenization pattern for any language, words only. Non-letters such as punctuation are ignored.
